Geldert (1925-1928) | partner = [[Marie Louise Habets]] (1945-1981)<ref>http://www.rhoenline.de/kathryn_hulme.html</ref> }} '''Kathryn Hulme''' (July 6, 1900 - August 25, 1981) was an American author and memoirist most noted for her novel ''[[The Nun's Story]]''. The book is often, mistakenly, understood to be semi-biographical. ==Writing== Her [[1956 in literature|1956]] book ''The Nun's Story'' was a best-selling novel which was made into an [[Academy awards|award-winning]] 1959 movie starring [[Audrey Hepburn]] and [[Peter Finch]]. Another work, ''The Undiscovered Country: A Spiritual Adventure'' published by Little, Brown & Co. was a description of her years as a student of mystic [[G. I. Gurdjieff]]. Hulme studied with Gurdjieff as part of a group of women known as "The Rope", which included eight members in all: [[Jane Heap]], [[Help:Disambiguation|Elizabeth Gordon]], [[Solita Solano]], [[Margaret Caroline Anderson]], [[Louise Davidson]] and [[Alice Rohrer]], besides them.<ref>[http://www.gurdjieff-legacy.org/70links/rope.htm The Rope] gurdjieff-legacy.org.</ref> She is also the author of ''Wild Place'', a description of her experiences as the UNRRA Director of the Polish Displaced Persons (DP) camp at Wildflecken, Germany, after WWII. This work won the Atlantic Non-Fiction Award in 1952. It was at Wildflecken that Hulme met a Belgian nurse and former nun named [[Marie Louise Habets]], who became her lifelong companion. ''The Nun's Story'' is a slightly fictionalized biographical account of Habets' life as a nun. No one questions that adults and children see the world differently. The former strive for understanding; the latter are captured by wonderâ€”even in the aftermath of a natural disaster. In her 1938 fictionalized autobiography ''[http://catalog.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB=local&BBID=10182336&v3=1 "We Lived as Children,"]'' San Francisco native Kathryn Hulme captured this difference, as her persona tells of watching San Francisco burn after the tragic 1906 earthquake. ==Bibliography== *''Arab Interlude'', Macrae Smith Company (Philadelphia), 1930 *''Desert Night'', The Macauley Company (New York), 1932 *''We lived as children'', A.A.
